messages: a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:22): I found something slower than an arlan
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:22): http://www.aerocomm.com/rf_data_modems/connexnet_serial-ethernet_converter.htm
995b15da895d895b607cb0175432d850 (03:25): cool.  I'm guessing its not for large-scale traffic, but for serial-console out-of-band stuff.
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:26): they sell a module that claims it'll work down to -110
995b15da895d895b607cb0175432d850 (03:26): interesting it speaks IP
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:26): at full rate
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:26): saw a crazy little setup today
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:26): a 900 PCI card of some sort
995b15da895d895b607cb0175432d850 (03:26): I've got a number of RJ45-DB9 or DB25 adapters
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:26): used in a fire alarm computer
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:27): or, at least, it had a 900-ish looking yagi connected to it
995b15da895d895b607cb0175432d850 (03:27): and I also have a balun system that gives 500 metres over cat5 for composite video
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:27): the alarm people weren't around or I would have asked...  I'm guessing its something like those...  really slow, good sensitivity.
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:30): looking at my pac 900 yagi
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:30): that yagi was noticably bigger
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:30): hmm...  maybe 450+ UHF
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:32): http://cgi.ebay.com/Scope-UHF-POCSAG-radio-paging-system-fire-alarm_W0QQitemZ180009055677QQihZ008QQcategoryZ3314QQcmdZViewItem
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:32): yeah, its gotta be some crap like that
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:32): I bet its GMRS or a licensed UHF frequency near 500ish
995b15da895d895b607cb0175432d850 (03:33): probably real slow
995b15da895d895b607cb0175432d850 (03:33): all it has to say is "ID number, what happened"
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:33): better than Verizon's crappy tx
995b15da895d895b607cb0175432d850 (03:33): and maybe some authentication too
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:36): a smartcard was involved
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:36): or something that looked like a smartcard
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:36): all I know is
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:36): they threw the yagi
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:36): up in the ceiling, pointing back toward town
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:37): laid it on top of two half inch electrical conduits (metal)
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:37): fired it up
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:37): and left.
995b15da895d895b607cb0175432d850 (03:37): so no real aiming?
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:37): no aiming, and the metal conduit is totally screwing it up I'm sure
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:37): its a 7 element antenna iirc
995b15da895d895b607cb0175432d850 (03:37): must be hell powerfil output
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:38): my guess is short range
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:38): short distance
995b15da895d895b607cb0175432d850 (03:38): so....  disconenct it, and hook the core to one pipe and the shield to the other pipe
995b15da895d895b607cb0175432d850 (03:38): see what happens
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:38): how about I just rip the end off an extension cord and start sticking it in the BNC plug? :)
995b15da895d895b607cb0175432d850 (03:38): "Oh gosh look vern - the $placename signal has gone up tenfold in strength"
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:38): hahah probably
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:43): wow, I think I'm going to buy a couple of these UHF serial bridges, once I figure out what band they're using
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:43): would be interesting to drop on a GMRS (w/ license) channel, or even FRS :P
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:45): http://www.scope-uk.com/pdfs/connexions.pdf
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (03:49): J4k3: I'm interested in low-freq yet high-speed comms. will follow.
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (03:51): http://users.utu.fi/slaur/smc2632w-v2-3.jpg
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (03:51): DrDT: what do you consider "high speed"? :)
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (03:51): is that MMCX in that picture, i think it s
dcb48806bd2e5dfa482f12ba4eb2f4f0 (03:51): can someone helps me there?
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (03:52): Stormy: it definitely isn't. that's a testing connector
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (03:52): J4k3: "high speed" at those freqs is like 115kbit
dcb48806bd2e5dfa482f12ba4eb2f4f0 (03:52): nobody can helps me?
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (03:53): J4k3: calculating from the device size specs in that datasheet, the 1/4 wave antenna is about 13cm, so the wavelength would be 52cm
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (03:54): I have no idea what about 50cm would be in mhz, although I guess ~450mhz
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (03:55): wiBo: nobody knows what your question is, so no
dcb48806bd2e5dfa482f12ba4eb2f4f0 (03:55): when I type : iwlist scan, my device (wireless) eth1 is No Such device..
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (03:56): wiBo: how do you know the device is eth1? sounds like a driver problem
dcb48806bd2e5dfa482f12ba4eb2f4f0 (03:57): my broadcom BCM4318 is eth1
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (03:57): J4k3: apparently 50cm is the middle 600mhz band
dcb48806bd2e5dfa482f12ba4eb2f4f0 (03:57): my driver is: bcmwl5.inf
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (03:57): are you using ndis or the bcm driver?
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (03:57): wiBo: if you're using ndiswrapper, expect problems
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (03:57): if your using ndis then it's wlan0 not eth1
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (03:57): if your using the bcm driver it's eth1 not wlan0
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (03:58): I'd say try the open-source driver instead of ndiswrapper
dcb48806bd2e5dfa482f12ba4eb2f4f0 (03:58): I'm using the bcm driver
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (03:58): It works until you mess with it
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (03:58): i had it working well for a week
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (03:58): well then your driver wouldn't be a ,.inf file
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (03:58): it takes microcode from the windows driver
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (03:58): yes, exactly
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (03:59): i was forced back to the ndis driver after i blew up bcm
dcb48806bd2e5dfa482f12ba4eb2f4f0 (03:59): ok lol
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (03:59): but that's all going to get fixed this weekend hopefully
dcb48806bd2e5dfa482f12ba4eb2f4f0 (03:59): and where I can find a ndis driver?
dcb48806bd2e5dfa482f12ba4eb2f4f0 (03:59): for my 4318
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (03:59): you need to find the ndiswrapper
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (03:59): search the gentoo forums
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (03:59): i think that's where i saw the howto
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (03:59): wiBo: I wouldn't if I were you; try the open-source driver
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (03:59): DrDT, honestly the ndis is alot more stable
dcb48806bd2e5dfa482f12ba4eb2f4f0 (03:59): what is the 'open-source' driver ?
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (03:59): he's talking about the drive in 2.6.17
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (03:59): Stormy: I've heard the opposite
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (04:00): DrDT do you own one?
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (04:00): Stormy: a few, but I don't use them in Linux
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (04:00): and i'm using the ndis right now
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (04:00): if you can't move to that kernel
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (04:00): look into ndiswrapper
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (04:12): does anyone have the old guerlla wireless onmi directional directions?
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (04:24): Stormy: there were mirrors around I think
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (04:25): else I may have a copy somewhere
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (04:26): that looks like my copy, try it: http://www.olotwireless.net/catala/Maxrad.htm
0c281694b8d560521413604b35c64dbd (04:27): I bought 1/16th" rod instead of 3/64" rod, is it going to affect this much?
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (04:27): I don't think so, but you may need to change some calcs (prop. velocity?)
05346ab3db400d0ed757154ddb3f0800 (04:31): J4k3: heck this out, 140-220Ghz tx/rx kit: http://cgi.ebay.ca/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewItem&item=290007430078
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (04:51): thats wierd
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (04:51): Light-Lo band
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (04:52): thats quite a toy tho... sounds really useless on earth though
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (04:52): now...  150 miles up that'd be a completely different story
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (04:53): actually, I bet that alarm system is GSM or CDMA
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (04:53): that'd make sense too

a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (04:58): and the entire lack of decent antenna requirement.  Needed more than the little rubber ducky it came with for good signal (Cingular's tower is 4 miles away, through brick, steel, trees, a fence, etc) but it really didn't need a bigass maxrad yagi
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (04:58): that also explains the interference... one really pissed off GSM rig with unstable transmit :P
